body: An alert from ZAP or from your web browser?

Hmmm interesting looking at your screenshot what's the difference between a P request and an S request? 

Because there's a P request that returns 200/html, then a S that returns 200/html, then a S that returns 200/plain, then the S requests start returning 504/plain.
[Do you see the same sequence when ZAP isn't in place? As far as request types (parameters) and response content type...]

How are things set for ZAP's Local Proxy settings with regard to "Modify/Remove "Accept-Encoding" request-header" and "Always unzip gzipped content"

Looking at the "heartbeat" (or whatever) during a normal session each request is just over 30,000ms.

In ZAP try going Tools > Options > Connection and set your timeout as 35 sec.

> what's the difference between a P request and an S request? 

A P request is when I send a message, it's followed by one of to S requests(HTML). So there are two kind of S requests (because the "heartbeat" is an S request(plain) too). The type is plain when it contains the ZAP error.

> Do you see the same sequence when ZAP isn't in place?

I see only the requests related to a message that I send.

> How are things set for ZAP's Local Proxy settings with regard to "Modify/Remove "Accept-Encoding" request-header" and "Always unzip gzipped content"

They are booth checked.

> Looking at the "heartbeat" (or whatever) during a normal session each request is just over 30,000ms.
> In ZAP try going Tools > Options > Connection and set your timeout as 35 sec.

Default timeout is 20 seconds. **Setting it to 31 seconds allow the requests to not fail and to show up in ZAP**

No problem :)

Is the default timeout that breaks freenode's webchat(and other webapps I guess) not a problem?

I would say, no, IMHO a default of 20 seconds is enough for the majority of the cases (which can be easily changed if a higher value is required for a specific case).
Thoughts?

> a default of 20 seconds is enough for the majority of the cases (which can be easily changed if a higher value is required for a specific case).

As #2399 is fixed, it should be easier to spot such a case and think of increasing the timeout right?
Yeah, we could also change the error message to suggest that?
What is the current error message?

As you quoted in the original report:

> ZAP Error [java.net.SocketTimeoutException]: Read timed out
> 
> Stack Trace:
> java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out
>     at java.net.SocketInputStream.socketRead0(Native Method)
>     at java.net.SocketInputStream.socketRead(SocketInputStream.java:116)
>     .....

If we could separately catch SocketTimeoutException for proxied traffic (vs. Active scan or spider), we could supress the stack trace and add something like:
`A SocketTimeoutException occurred, consider adjusting ZAP's default time out in the Connection options panel.`
(Or something like that?)

Or something like: "Failed to connect to site: https:///www.example.com within 20 secs, check to see if the site is available and if so consider adjusting ZAP's default time out in the Connection options panel."

rename.from: Timeouts when using freenode's webchat through ZAP
rename.to: Show a more informative message on read timeouts through the proxy

issue.title: Show more informative error on proxy read timeout

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Change class ProxyThread to set a more informative error message into
the body of the HTTP response, indicating that a read timeout occurred
while reading the response after the seconds defined in the Connection
options panel (as proposed in the issue report).

Fix #2400 - Show a more informative message on read timeouts through the
proxy

body: This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
